intro: Ophrys speculum nothosubsp. jeanpertii, commonly known as the mimic orchid, is a rare and specialized orchid species native to specific regions of southern Europe. It is characterized by its intricate floral structure, which closely resembles the appearance of female bees, a feature evolved to facilitate pollination through sexual deception. The plant typically grows in open, sunny habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes, where it thrives in well-drained soils. Its flowers are usually pale yellow to brown in color, with intricate patterns that mimic the visual cues of its pollinators. Due to habitat loss and limited distribution, this nothosubspecies is considered endangered and requires conservation efforts to ensure its survival.
